title: A Preliminary Exploration with GPT-4o Voice Mode
author: Yu-Xiang Lin (National Taiwan University), Chih-Kai Yang (National Taiwan University), Wei-Chih Chen (National Taiwan University), Chen-An Li (National Taiwan University), Chien-yu Huang (National Taiwan University), Xuanjun Chen (National Taiwan University), Hung-yi Lee (National Taiwan University), Haohe Liu (University of Surrey)
relevance_why: The assessment of GPT-4o's capabilities in audio processing and speech recognition aligns with Haohe Liu's focus on audio and speech technology, particularly in the use of advanced models for sound manipulation and generation.
background: The study evaluates the performance of GPT-4o, a multimodal large language model, across various audio-related tasks including speech recognition and music analysis.
contribution: This paper introduces an exploration of GPT-4o's performance in significant audio tasks to assess its technical capabilities, revealing both strengths and weaknesses.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models struggled with tasks involving audio duration prediction and instrument classification, showing inconsistency in safety-related task refusals.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work offers a detailed comparative analysis of GPT-4o, highlighting its improved robustness against hallucination in contrast to existing audio-language models.

key_innovation: Focuses on an end-to-end evaluation across a wide range of benchmarks, enabling a holistic view of the model's capabilities, especially in reasoning and audio comprehension.
real_world_impact: Insights gained from this research may enhance future audio-technology models, facilitating their integration into voice assistants and interactive systems.
limitations: The report highlights inconsistency in refusal rates for similar tasks based on dataset quality and instructions, which may affect model evaluation.

new_terms.multimodal: **Multimodal** refers to the ability of a system to process and integrate information from different modalities, such as audio, text, and visual data.
